title: Housing Market’s Autumn Boost Delayed in the U.K.
text:
While the start of September usually marks the beginning of an autumn boost to the U.K.’s housing market, it could be on hold this year as Brexit uncertainty heightens across the nation, according to a report Monday from Rightmove.



The average price of homes listed for sale between Aug. 11 and Sept. 7, fell 0.2% compared to the previous four-week period, equating to a drop of £730 (US$906).

It marks the first time since September 2010 that this time of year has seen monthly price falls, the online property portal said.



The average U.K. asking price now stands at £304,770 (US$378,553).



Along with a fall in asking prices, Rightmove also reported a 5.5% drop in the number of sales agreed upon—the first step in purchasing a property, before an official sale has occurred.



The decline marked a stark reversal from the 6.1% increase in sales agreed in the previous four-week period, when it appeared U.K. buyers were rushing to secure a good deal before October’s Brexit deadline.



Since then, Brexit uncertainty has worsened amid a contentious parliament shutdown.

Though the shutdown is being challenged, Members of Parliament are currently set to return to work two weeks before the current Brexit deadline of Oct. 31, which is when Prime Minister Boris Johnson has pledged to leave the EU, with or without a deal in place.



“Many have got used to living in the jaws of uncertainty since the referendum over three years ago, and have been getting on with their lives and housing moves,” Miles Shipside, Rightmove director and housing market analyst, said in the report. “However, as we approach yet another Brexit deadline, there are signs that the increasing gnashing of teeth is causing some to hesitate.”



This year’s autumn bounce is “a late starter at best,” Mr. Shipside said. “And if uncertainty persists then the autumn term could be missed altogether and its activities be delayed until the new year.”
